#Text=Tell if a Watermelon Is
#Text=Bad
#Text=Watermelon is a delicious summer treat , but to protect your health , it ’s important to know if a watermelon is bad .
#Text=One way you could discover whether your watermelon is bad is by checking for mold or a foul smell .
#Text=You could also use the expiration date to tell if the watermelon is bad .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Identifying Signs of Spoilage
#Text=Check for mold on the outside .
#Text=Mold or dark-colored spots on the outside of the watermelon could indicate that it has gone bad .
#Text=The mold might be black , white , or green , and have a fuzzy appearance .
#Text=Look for a healthy color outside .
#Text=The watermelon should have either a consistent pine green shade or a striped appearance .
#Text=Striped watermelons have alternating lime-green and darker pine-colored stripes .
#Text=Look for a deep pink or red inside .
#Text=These colors indicate the watermelon is healthy .
#Text=If your watermelon is a different color ( black , for instance ) , do not eat it .
#Text=Different varieties of watermelon have different internal appearances .
#Text=Desert King , Tendergold , Yellow Baby , and Yellow Doll watermelons have yellow or orange flesh .
#Text=Beware of gritty and dry watermelon flesh .
#Text=When watermelon is no longer good , the crisp flesh will start to shrivel .
#Text=The flesh might even be pulling away from the seeds .
#Text=In other cases , the watermelon might become slimy and mushy .
#Text=Smell the watermelon before cutting into it .
#Text=A healthy , edible watermelon should smell sweet and fresh .
#Text=If it smells tangy or sour , it ’s gone bad and should be thrown it away .
#Text=Measuring the Freshness Using Dates
#Text=Use the expiration date .
#Text=If you ’re eating pre-cut watermelon you bought from the market , the container should include an eat-by , best-by , or other expiration date .
#Text=This date lets you know how long you have until the watermelon goes bad .
#Text=Eat cut watermelon within five days .
#Text=Properly stored , sliced watermelon will stay good three to five days .
#Text=Make eating it a priority to prevent it from going bad .
#Text=Eat unrefrigerated , uncut watermelon within 10 days .
#Text=After about a week , uncut , unrefrigerated watermelon will start to turn .
#Text=Eat uncut , unrefrigerated watermelon as soon as possible .
#Text=Do n’t eat refrigerated , uncut watermelon after 2-3 weeks .
#Text=After about two weeks , refrigerated , uncut watermelon will start to turn .
#Text=To prevent your uncut , refrigerated watermelon from going bad , eat it within two weeks of purchase .
#Text=Extending the Shelf Life of Watermelon
#Text=Refrigerate your whole or sliced watermelon .
#Text=Watermelons are typically refrigerated at a temperature of 13 degrees Celsius ( 55 F ) .
#Text=Storing your fruit at 21 Celsius ( 70 F ) will increase its lycopene and beta-carotene content ( both of which are important antioxidants ) .
#Text=Store cut watermelon in an airtight container .
#Text=A resealable bag or container is the best place for watermelon .
#Text=This will preserve its flavor and freshness .
#Text=In a pinch , wrap your watermelon tightly in aluminum foil or plastic wrap .
#Text=Use caution when freezing watermelon .
#Text=Some people advise against freezing watermelon altogether , since thawing or cutting open a frozen watermelon piece could cause the juice to drip out .
#Text=If you decide to live on the wild side and want to freeze your watermelon , place it in airtight containers or heavy-duty freezer bags .
#Text=The watermelon will stay good for 10-12 months .
#Text=Quick Summary
